intro: Aethusa cynapium subsp. gigantea, commonly known as giant hemlock, is a member of the Apiaceae family and is characterized by its tall, slender stems and feathery, finely divided leaves. It produces small, greenish-white flowers arranged in umbels, typical of the carrot family. The plant is native to Europe and is often found in moist, shady habitats such as woodlands and stream banks. It is also known for its strong, aromatic scent and has been used historically in herbal medicine. However, it is toxic to humans and animals, containing compounds that can cause severe health issues if ingested.
